abstract.text: Present your app’s content in widgets with SwiftUI views.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: Widgets can use many, but not all, SwiftUI views to present content. Use the
views listed below to implement your widget’s view.
Widgets can’t use UIKit or AppKit views wrapped with

abstract.text: Extend the reach of your app by creating widgets, watch complications, Live Activities, and controls.
An adaptive background view that provides a standard appearance based on the
the widget’s environment.
Include buttons or toggles in a widget or Live Activity to offer app functionality without launching the app.

doc://com.apple.WidgetKit/documentation/.title: Adding interactivity to widgets and Live Activities

abstract.text: Implement glanceable views with WidgetKit and SwiftUI.

doc://com.apple.WidgetKit/documentation/.title: Creating views for widgets, Live Activities, and watch complications

abstract.text: Show up-to-date, time-based information in your widget even when it
isn’t running.
Create widgets that support additional platforms and adapt to their context.

doc://com.apple.WidgetKit/documentation/.title: Preparing widgets for additional platforms, contexts, and appearances

abstract.text: Values that indicate different widget locations.
An angular gradient.
A type-erased view.
The background style in the current context.
A control that initiates an action.
A view type that supports immediate mode drawing.
A capsule shape aligned inside the frame of the view containing it.
A circle centered on the frame of the view containing it.
A representation of a color that adapts to a given context.
A shape that is replaced by an inset version of the current container shape. If no container shape was defined, is replaced by a rectangle.
A visual element that can be used to separate other content.
An ellipse aligned inside the frame of the view containing it.
A view that doesn’t contain any content.
A view type that compares itself against its previous value and prevents its child updating if its new value is the same as its old value.
A style for rasterizing vector shapes.
A structure that computes views on demand from an underlying collection of identified data.
The foreground style in the current context.
A proxy for access to the size and coordinate space (for anchor resolution) of the container view.
A container view that defines its content as a function of its own size and coordinate space.
A color gradient represented as an array of color stops, each having a parametric location value.
A description of a row or a column in a lazy grid.
A type that collects multiple instances of a content type — like views, scenes, or commands — into a single unit.
A stylized view, with an optional label, that visually collects a logical grouping of content.
A view that arranges its subviews in a horizontal line.
A view that displays an image.
A shape style that fills a shape by repeating a region of an image.
A standard label for user interface items, consisting of an icon with a title.
A container view that arranges its child views in a grid that grows horizontally, creating items only as needed.
A view that arranges its children in a line that grows horizontally, creating items only as needed.
A container view that arranges its child views in a grid that grows vertically, creating items only as needed.
A view that arranges its children in a line that grows vertically, creating items only as needed.
A linear gradient.
A control for navigating to a URL.
A wrapper that you use to integrate an AppKit view into your SwiftUI view hierarchy.
A shape with a translation offset transform applied to it.
A structure that computes views and disclosure groups on demand from an underlying collection of tree-structured, identified data.
The outline of a 2D shape.
A radial gradient.
A rectangular shape aligned inside the frame of the view containing it.
A shape with a rotation transform applied to it.
A rectangular shape with rounded corners, aligned inside the frame of the view containing it.
A shape with a scale transform applied to it.
A container view that you can use to add hierarchy within certain views.
A style used to visually indicate selection following platform conventional colors and behaviors.
A style appropriate for foreground separator or border lines.
A flexible space that expands along the major axis of its containing stack layout, or on both axes if not contained in a stack.
The characteristics of a stroke that traces a path.
A view that displays one or more lines of read-only text.
A control that toggles between on and off states.
A shape with an affine transform applied to it.
A View created from a swift tuple of View values.
A wrapper for a UIKit view that you use to integrate that view into your SwiftUI view hierarchy.
A view that arranges its subviews in a vertical line.
A view that overlays its subviews, aligning them in both axes.
SwiftUI is a modern way to declare user interfaces for any Apple platform. Create beautiful, dynamic apps faster than ever before.
